        knowledge:
        Consolidated Content:
Manchego cheese is made in the La Mancha region of Spain from the milk of sheep of the Manchega breed. It can be made from pasteurized or raw milk, and the only permitted additives are natural rennet or another approved coagulating enzyme and salt. True Manchego cheese must be made from the whole milk of Manchega sheep raised in La Mancha. The cheese is hard, with a strong taste, mild bite, and greasy texture. It is aged between 60 days and 2 years. There are many individual types of queso manchego depending on curing time and tradition, and some are submerged in olive oil while curing.
